title: 106_hr4031
content: The judicial structure of Guam is outlined in Section 1. The judicial authority of Guam is vested in the District Court of Guam, the Supreme Court of Guam, and the Superior Court of Guam, as outlined in the Organic Act of Guam. The Supreme Court of Guam has the power to create divisions within the Superior Court and other local courts. The courts of record for Guam include the District Court of Guam, the Supreme Court of Guam, and the Superior Court of Guam. The Supreme Court of Guam is the highest court with original jurisdiction over various proceedings and appeals in Guam. It can issue orders and writs to support its jurisdiction. The Supreme Court of Guam has appellate, supervisory, and original jurisdiction over the judicial branch of Guam. It supervises the Superior Court and other courts, hears appeals with a panel of three justices, makes rules for court administration, and governs attorney and judicial ethics in Guam. The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Guam oversees the conduct and discipline of lawyers, presides over the court, and has administrative authority over the judicial branch. They can issue administrative orders and make decisions on appeals before they are heard on their merits or dismiss appeals for lack of jurisdiction. The Superior Court of Guam and other local courts have original and appellate jurisdiction over all causes in Guam, subject to the District Court of Guam's jurisdiction. Justices and judges' qualifications and duties are governed by Guam laws and court rules. Technical amendments are made to the Organic Act of Guam, including changes to the Supreme Court of Guam's name and references to the appellate court.
